View
Special Issue: "Ecology, Dynamics, and Management of Starfish Populations"
Project
Journal of Marine Science and Engineering https://www.mdpi.com/journal/jmse/special_issues/cl_ecology_management_starfish Dear Colleagues, Starfish or seastars (Phylum Echinodermata: Class Asteroidea) are one of the most recognisable and iconic organisms in the marine environment. They are found in a variety of habitats and play an important role in shaping community structure within these habitats. The ecological and economic ramifications of irruptions or crashes in starfish populations have been well documented. For example, outbreaks of the crown-of-thorns starfish (Acanthaster spp.) have led to widespread mortality of reef corals in the Indo-Pacific region, along with negative consequences for a vast diversity of coral-dependent species and the tourism industry. Likewise, the introduction and subsequent invasion of the North Pacific seastar (Asterias amurensis) in Tasmanian waters has had a detrimental impact on native fauna and resulted in significant economic losses for the local shellfish industry. Conversely, starfish wasting syndrome has led to catastrophic declines in the populations of starfish species, which are dominant predators in intertidal (Pisaster ochraceus) and subtidal (Pycnopodia helianthoides) communities along the Pacific coast of North America, thereby triggering trophic cascades. Managing the causes and consequences of fluctuations in starfish populations has become increasingly important and urgent, especially against the backdrop of unprecedented climate change. This Special Issue provides a platform for important research on the ecology, dynamics, and management of starfish populations—including but not limited to surveys to monitor the dynamics of starfish populations, studies investigating the causes and ecological impacts of the boom and bust of starfish populations, and advances in management practices to control outbreaks or arrest declines in starfish populations. Research articles, review articles, as well as short communications are invited from now until 15 January 2021. Dr. Ciemon Caballes (James Cook University) Prof. Maria Byrne (University of Sydney) Guest Editors
